questions.text: Identify the pathology and it’s treatment.

questions.explanation:

  • • SUBLINGUAL GLAND
  • • SUBLINGUAL GLAND

  • • Ranula is a mucous extravasation cyst of sublingual salivary gland
  • • Its treatment includes excision along with affected sublingual gland

questions.text: Which of these lymph node groups are removed in lateral neck dissection for oropharyngeal cancer?

  • • Lateral: 2,3,4
  • • MRND: 1,2,3,4,5

questions.text: A child is brought by his parents with vomiting of curdled milk. Upon investigation, a gastric disease is diagnosed, and a procedure is done as shown. Which of these is correct about the pathology?

options.label: A
options.text: It presents in the weaning period

options.label: B
options.text: The disease is diagnosed on upper GI endoscopy

options.label: C
options.text: Surgery involves cutting the serosa and muscularis while preserving the mucosa

questions.correct_answer: C. Surgery involves cutting the serosa and muscularis while preserving the mucosa
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The disease is Infantile pyloric stenosis, which presents in 2-8 weeks of life. It is diagnosed on USG abdomen.
  • • The disease is Infantile pyloric stenosis, which presents in 2-8 weeks of life.
  • • It is diagnosed on USG abdomen.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with swelling as shown. All of these are true regarding the swelling except?

options.label: A
options.text: Swelling shows vertical mobility but not horizontal

questions.correct_answer: A. Swelling shows vertical mobility but not horizontal
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Parotid swellings like pleomorphic adenoma show lateral mobility, but restricted in vertical direction- curtain sign
  • • Parotid swellings like pleomorphic adenoma show lateral mobility, but restricted in vertical direction- curtain sign

questions.text: What is the most frequent cause of adrenal incidentaloma?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

  • • Functional tumors: Cortex: Conn’s, Cushing’s
  • • Medulla: Pheochromocytoma

questions.text: Bisgaard regimen is used in the management of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Bisgaard regimen is conservative management of venous ulcer.
  • • Bisgaard regimen is conservative management of venous ulcer.

questions.text: A patient with history of peripheral arterial disease presents with difficulty in walking due to pain in his legs suggestive of intermittent claudication. The best initial combination of management for this patient is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • For many patients with claudication a structured exercise programme of at least 2 hours of exercise per week for 3 months in combination with smoking cessation will lead to sustained improvement in claudication distance Even when the lipid is normal a statin should be prescribed as it may atherosclerotic plaques and protect against cardiac death independently of baseline serum lipid levels. An antiplatelet agent is also necessary: global guidelines recommend 75 mg per day of clopidogrel or 75 mg per day of aspirin as an alternative. Other agents, such as vasodilators, are unlikely to provide benefit
  • • For many patients with claudication a structured exercise programme of at least 2 hours of exercise per week for 3 months in combination with smoking cessation will lead to sustained improvement in claudication distance
  • • Even when the lipid is normal a statin should be prescribed as it may atherosclerotic plaques and protect against cardiac death independently of baseline serum lipid levels.
  • • An antiplatelet agent is also necessary: global guidelines recommend 75 mg per day of clopidogrel or 75 mg per day of aspirin as an alternative. Other agents, such as vasodilators, are unlikely to provide benefit
  • • An antiplatelet agent is also necessary:

questions.text: Best graft for aortic dissection is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Dacron

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Aortic dissection: Dacron CABG: LIMA
  • • Aortic dissection: Dacron
  • • CABG: LIMA

questions.text: What is the maximum flow of gas permissible from the device shown in laparoscopy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

  • • Explanation:

questions.text: During thyroidectomy, inferior thyroid artery is ligated?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Near ligation of ITA close to the thyroid ensures blood supply to parathyroids

questions.text: A 25-year-old male was brought to the emergency department after being struck on his head by the house door and temporary fainting. On examination, his sensorium was intact. NCCT head was performed and was a normal study. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Normal CT after mild/moderate head trauma with loss of consciousness implies concussion. EDH will show CT abnormality DAI will show poor GCS after severe trauma.
  • • Normal CT after mild/moderate head trauma with loss of consciousness implies concussion.
  • • Normal CT after mild/moderate head trauma with loss of consciousness implies concussion.
  • • EDH will show CT abnormality
  • • EDH will show CT abnormality
  • • DAI will show poor GCS after severe trauma.
  • • DAI will show poor GCS after severe trauma.

questions.text: The RLN is at greatest risk of injury during thyroidectomy at what site?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Berry’s ligament: Posterior condensation of pretracheal fascia - Site of injury to RLN Tubercle of Zuckerkandl: Posterolateral portion of thyroid
  • • Berry’s ligament: Posterior condensation of pretracheal fascia - Site of injury to RLN
  • • Tubercle of Zuckerkandl: Posterolateral portion of thyroid
  • • Anatomy
  • • Anatomy

questions.text: After total thyroidectomy under GA, the patient was breathless immediately on extubation. Re-intubation attempts were unsuccessful. What is the most probable reason?
questions.correct_answer: B. Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve damage
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Immediate stridor and difficulty in extubation is suggestive of bilateral RLN injury.
  • • Immediate stridor and difficulty in extubation is suggestive of bilateral RLN injury.

questions.text: In a patient who presents to the casualty with an RTA, what is the correct sequence of management?

options.label: A
options.text: Cervical spine stabilization, intubation, IV cannulation, CECT

options.label: B
options.text: Intubation, cervical spine stabilization, IV cannulation, CECT

options.label: C
options.text: Cervical spine stabilization, IV Cannulation, intubation, CECT

options.label: D
options.text: Intubation, IV cannulation, cervical spine stabilization, CECT

questions.correct_answer: A. Cervical spine stabilization, intubation, IV cannulation, CECT
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • First step in Trauma:
  • • First step in Trauma:
  • • Airway assessment + C spine immobilisation
  • • Airway assessment + C spine immobilisation
  • • C- spine should be stabilised prior to intubation.

questions.text: A 42- years old pryearing to ER following penetrating trauma to thorax. On examination BP was 80/50mmHg; pulse was 110/min, the neck veins were engorged, and breaths sounds were normal while there was dampening of heart sounds. The next best management is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Suspected cardiac tamponade:
  • • Suspected cardiac tamponade:
  • • 1 st step: eFAST
  • • Management: thoracotomy and repair

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with a stab wound to the abdomen 2 cm above the umbilicus. He appears diaphoretic. His blood pressure is 95/ 70 and pulse rate is 115 beats/ minute. His stab wound is not bleeding, and his abdomen is tender diffusely. Which of the following management options is most appropriate?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In penetrating trauma with features of peritonitis, laparotomy is done.
  • • In penetrating trauma with features of peritonitis, laparotomy is done.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient has been diagnosed with proximal transverse colon carcinoma. The physician recommends an extended right colectomy as a treatment option. Which arteries should be ligated at the root during an extended right colectomy to prevent the spread of cancer in proximal transverse colon carcinoma?

options.label: A
options.text: Ileocolic, right colic and right branch of middle colic

options.label: B
options.text: Ileocolic, right colic, stem of middle colic, left colic

options.label: C
options.text: Ileocolic, right colic and trunk of middle colic

options.label: D
options.text: Ileocolic, right colic and left branch of middle colic

questions.correct_answer: C. Ileocolic, right colic and trunk of middle colic
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Right hemicolectomy: Ileo-colic + right colic + right branch of middle colic Extended right hemicolectomy: Ileocolic+ right colic + main middle colic.
  • • Right hemicolectomy: Ileo-colic + right colic + right branch of middle colic
  • • Extended right hemicolectomy: Ileocolic+ right colic + main middle colic.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Meckel’s diverticulum?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a remnant of the vitellointestinal duct

options.label: B
options.text: It is found on the mesenteric side of the ileum

options.label: C
options.text: It may contain heterotopic epithelium of the gastric, colonic or pancreatic type

options.label: D
options.text: Meckel’s diverticulum in inguinal or femoral hernia is described as Littre's hernia

questions.correct_answer: B. It is found on the mesenteric side of the ileum
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Meckels is found on antimesenteric border of ileum.
  • • Meckels is found on antimesenteric border of ileum.

questions.text: A 58-year-old female complains of dull aching pain in right iliac fossa. On examination, gross pallor was found, and a mass was palpable in right iliac fossa. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Carcinoma ascending colon

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Elderly patient with RIF mass and pallor is likely to be colonic cancer.
  • • Elderly patient with RIF mass and pallor is likely to be colonic cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following is wrong regarding superior mesenteric artery syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: Superior mesenteric artery is compressed by third part of duodenum at the ligament of Treitz attachment

options.label: B
options.text: Superior mesenteric artery has a normal angle between 38-65 degree in relation to duodenum

options.label: C
options.text: Superior mesenteric artery syndrome is characterized by an angle less than 25 degree due to loss of intervening mesenteric pad of fat

options.label: D
options.text: Acute presentation is usually characterised by signs and symptoms of duodenal obstruction

questions.correct_answer: A. Superior mesenteric artery is compressed by third part of duodenum at the ligament of Treitz attachment
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Duodenum is compressed by SMA in SMA syndrome.
  • • Duodenum is compressed by SMA in SMA syndrome.

questions.text: A young boy presented to the casualty with history of fever, pain abdomen and vomiting. On examination, he was febrile with a pulse rate of 104/mm. What sign is the surgical attending trying to elicit below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • McBurney point tenderness in RIF is suggestive of acute appendicitis.
  • • McBurney point tenderness in RIF is suggestive of acute appendicitis.

questions.text: A patient presents to her primary care physician with vague complaints of epigastric pain. X-ray of the abdomen is suggestive of a type II (paraesophageal) hiatal hernia, and this is later confirmed on CT with oral contrast. The patient is recommended to undergo surgical repair. The goal of surgery is to prevent which complication?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Rolling type of hiatus hernia is likely to undergo volvulus.
  • • Rolling type of hiatus hernia is likely to undergo volvulus.

questions.text: While doing emergency laparotomy for intestinal obstruction which organ will you first visualize to determine whether it’s small bowel or large bowel obstruction?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Dilated cecum implies colonic obstruction, while collapsed cecum implies small bowel obstruction
  • • Dilated cecum implies colonic obstruction, while collapsed cecum implies small bowel obstruction

questions.text: A 45-year-old lady presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain. An abdominal ultrasound reveals the presence of multiple gallstones with no evidence of wall thickening. The bile duct diameter is measured at 12 mm, and serum bilirubin levels are mildly elevated at 1.8. The patient's alkaline phosphatase levels are significantly elevated at 680, and the gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT) levels are raised by 5 times. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Dilated CBD in setting of gall stones implies risk of CBD stones, for which MRCP should be done next.
  • • Dilated CBD in setting of gall stones implies risk of CBD stones, for which MRCP should be done next.

questions.text: Which of the following malignancies is least likely to lead to the finding in the image shown?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Left breast phylloides tumor

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Phylloides tumors spreads hematogenously if malignant.
  • • Phylloides tumors spreads hematogenously if malignant.

questions.text: A 57-year-old previously alcoholic man with a history of pancreatitis presents with hematemesis. Endoscopy reveals isolated gastric varices in the absence of esophageal varices. His liver function tests are normal, and he has no stigmata of end-stage liver disease. Ultrasound examination demonstrates normal portal flow but a thrombosed splenic vein. He undergoes banding, which is initially successful, but he subsequently rebleeds during the same hospitalization. Attempts to control the bleeding endoscopically are unsuccessful. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Splenic vein thrombosis causing left-sided portal hypertension is managed by splenectomy
  • • Splenic vein thrombosis causing left-sided portal hypertension is managed by splenectomy

questions.text: All except one are correct with respect to liver hemangioma:

options.label: A
options.text: Most common benign tumor of liver

options.text: OC Pills have added risk in its development

questions.text: Which of these is incorrect for Adenocarcinoma Pancreas?

options.label: A
options.text: Head of the pancreas is the MC site

options.label: B
options.text: Painless obstructive Jaundice is seen early

options.label: D
options.text: Pancreaticoduodenectomy is the standard of care surgery

questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

  • • Painless jaundice is a late feature of pancreatic cancer.
  • • Painless jaundice is a late feature of pancreatic cancer.

questions.text: Which of these is the most common route of pyogenic liver abscess?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Biliary tract pathology is the most common source (35%), followed by portal spread from the gastrointestinal tract, including diverticulitis and appendicitis (20%). Other unusual etiologies include contiguous spread from subphrenic or intra-abdominal collections, bacteremia secondary to trauma
  • • Biliary tract pathology is the most common source (35%), followed by portal spread from the gastrointestinal tract, including diverticulitis and appendicitis (20%).
  • • Other unusual etiologies include contiguous spread from subphrenic or intra-abdominal collections, bacteremia secondary to trauma

questions.text: All are indications of ERCP except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Type II choledochal cyst

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • ERCP with cyst drainage is done for type 3 choledochal cyst
  • • ERCP with cyst drainage is done for type 3 choledochal cyst

questions.text: In the patient as shown below, chest wall closure has been achieved by using which flap?

options.label: A
options.text: Transversely oriented rectus abdominis muscle flap

options.label: B
options.text: Vertically oriented rectus abdominis muscle flap

questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Flap harvested from chest is PMMC Rectus abdominus flaps are harvested from lower abdomen
  • • Flap harvested from chest is PMMC
  • • Rectus abdominus flaps are harvested from lower abdomen

questions.text: What is the safest strategy of treatment for a patient with an inhalational burn injury who has presented within 4-5 hours?

options.label: B
options.text: O2 therapy with well well-fitting face mask

questions.explanation:
Ans. D

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The burned airway creates problems for the patient by swelling and, if not managed proactively, can completely occlude the upper airway. The treatment is to secure the airway with an endotracheal tube until the swelling has subsided, which is usually after about 48 hours The time frame from burn to airway occlusion is usually between 4 and 24 hours
  • • The burned airway creates problems for the patient by swelling and, if not managed proactively, can completely occlude the upper airway. The treatment is to secure the airway with an endotracheal tube until the swelling has subsided, which is usually after about 48 hours
  • • The time frame from burn to airway occlusion is usually between 4 and 24 hours

questions.text: A 59-year-old male with a smoking history of 35 pack years presented with sudden painless swellings in the left scrotal sac and hematuria. The swellings are painless and have cord-like consistency. On laboratory investigation, Alpha-fetoprotein and lactate dehydrogenase were negative. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Left Renal cell carcinoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Elderly smoker male with sudden onset left varicocele and hematuria is likely to be a left RCC.
  • • Elderly smoker male with sudden onset left varicocele and hematuria is likely to be a left RCC.

questions.text: A 67-year-old chronic heavy smoker presents with 2 weeks history of frank hematuria. USG pelvis shows a filling defect in the bladder. Most probable diagnosis:
questions.correct_answer: D. Transitional cell carcinoma of bladder
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Transitional cell carcinoma of bladder

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Bladder lesion in an elderly smoker is likely to be a transitional cell CA
  • • Bladder lesion in an elderly smoker is likely to be a transitional cell CA

questions.text: ESWL is contraindicated in the following stones except?

options.label: D
options.text: 10 mm stone in first trimester of pregnancy

questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Lower calyceal stone is a contra-indication to ESWL
  • • Lower calyceal stone is a contra-indication to ESWL

questions.text: Which of these is an incorrect statement about transurethral prostatectomy (TURP)?

options.label: A
options.text: Retrograde ejaculation is the most common complaint

options.label: B
options.text: Scissor is used to cut/dissect tissue

options.label: D
options.text: Can be done in the same setting as in cystoscopy

questions.correct_answer: B. Scissor is used to cut/dissect tissue
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:

  • • Resectotome with cautery is used for TURP.
